pageData.text: The senses enable us to detect changes in our environment. In this investigation, the student will conduct experiments to test the <button class='glossary-text'>special senses</button>: taste, smell, vision, hearing, and equilibrium. The investigation should be carried out with the assistance of a test subject. Over the course of several activities, the student will make connections between the anatomy of sensory structures and their functions.

Note for students:
The sensory tests performed in this investigation are for educational purposes and should not be used for diagnosis of medical conditions. If the results seem unusual, seek advice from a medical professional.

pageData.text: Do smells bring back memories for you? Many people report experiencing a clear memory of a distinct time, location, or event when they encounter a particular smell, such as freshly baked bread, rotten eggs, chlorine, or popcorn. Memory, smell, and emotions are closely linked, most likely because of the structure of the brain. The <button class='glossary-text'>olfactory bulb</button> connects the nose to the base of the brain and the base has a direct connection to the amygdala (an almond-shaped mass of gray matter this is responsible for processing emotion) and to the hippocampus (an area linked to memory, emotion, and the autonomic nervous system).

Scent-marketing strategies try to take advantage of the subconscious nature of smells and emotion to increase the time a customer stays in-store, customer loyalty, and customer spending. For example, the athletic-clothing company Nike uses smells reminiscent of a rubber basketball shoe scraping against a gym floor, or a soccer cleat tearing into green grass, in its brick-and-mortar locations. Nike hopes that when people smell these things, they have a fond association with the brand.

pageData.desc: A mug with a warm beverage and a bowl of popcorn on a table in front of a fire in a fireplace.
pageData.altText: A mug with a warm beverage and a bowl of popcorn on a table in front of a fire in a fireplace.

pageData.text: There are two broad categories of senses: general and special. The <button class='glossary-text'>general senses</button> include touch, pressure, pain, temperature, vibration, and <button class='glossary-text'>proprioception</button> (body position). Specialized nerve cells, called <button class='glossary-text'>sensory receptors</button>, are located throughout the skin, muscles, and tendons; they detect the general senses. In contrast, the <button class='glossary-text'>special senses</button>—taste (gustation), smell (olfaction), vision, hearing (audition), and equilibrium (balance)—are detected via sensory receptors associated with dedicated sensory organs.

Our sense organs, together with the nervous system, allow us to detect and respond to changes in the environment. The ability to respond to stimuli is essential for <button class='glossary-text'>homeostasis</button>—the dynamic, internal equilibrium the body sustains when in good health. When sensory receptors are triggered, they send information to the brain, which interprets the stimuli that are experienced. Thus, our very perception of reality comes from the interpretation of sensory information.

For each type of sensory reception, individual receptor cells provide information in an “all or nothing” manner. A stimulus is either sufficient to cause a sensory receptor to transmit a nerve impulse to the central nervous system, or it is not. Some sensory receptor cells respond only to a certain stimulus or set of stimuli. For instance, a light receptor cell in the eye may respond only to red light. If a light receptor for red light detects red, it discharges. A receptor cell will only transmit in response to a change in the stimulus to which it is sensitive. Nerve impulses travel through nerve fibers to the brain, where the impulses are processed. By analyzing and interpreting all the inputs from the sense organs, the brain allows us to experience sensory perception. If an injury damages the nerves associated with a sense organ, the brain can no longer obtain accurate information even if the sense organ is healthy and receiving input from stimuli.
In this investigation, you will explore the special senses of taste, smell, vision, hearing, and equilibrium. A test subject will be needed for most of these activities.

pageData.subTitle: Taste
pageData.text: The sense of taste is primarily restricted to the tongue, where most of the <button class='glossary-text'>taste buds</button> are located (Figure 1). Most taste buds reside in projections from the surface of the tongue called <button class='glossary-text'>papillae</button>. Each papilla contains multiple taste buds, which open to the outside of the papilla through tiny taste pores. A taste bud is composed of different types of gustatory epithelial cells. Slender extensions of these cells, called microvilli, project from the taste pore. Chemicals must be dissolved in saliva or other solvents to stimulate the taste buds. These chemicals, called <button class='glossary-text'>tastants</button>, interact with receptors in the microvilli.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of the relationship between the tongue, a papilla, and a taste bud; the detailed structure of a taste bud is also shown.

pageData.text:
There are five basic taste responses:
  1. Sweet: in response to the hydroxyl groups of a molecule
  2. Sour: in response to hydrogen ions, H+, in acids
  3. Salty: in response to inorganic metallic ions, such as Na+ and K+
  4. Bitter: in response to alkaloids (nitrogenous bases having complex ring structures) including quinine, morphine, and nicotine, and some nonalkaloid substances, such as acetylsalicylic acid (the active ingredient in aspirin)
  5. Umami: a “deliciously savory” taste in response to the amino acids glutamate and aspartate.
The sense of taste is not necessarily uniform. Bitterness can be detected at 1 part per million, whereas sweetness is detectable at a concentration of 1 part in 200 parts. The higher sensitivity for bitterness is probably a safety mechanism. Most poisons are bitter alkaloids; thus, the taste of bitterness may help trigger involuntary vomiting in case of poison ingestion. Furthermore, some substances can be tasted by certain individuals and not by others. These responses are, at least partially, genetically controlled.

Tongue mapping is used to determine which areas of the tongue respond to the basic tastes. This has long been a traditional class activity. It is based on early reports that some parts of the tongue respond more strongly than others to four of the taste stimuli: sweet, sour, salty, and bitter. These reports led to the idea that each taste has its own dedicated type of <button class='glossary-text'>taste bud</button>. However, more recent findings indicate that, although a taste bud may be more sensitive to a specific taste, any taste bud can, in fact, respond to any of the basic tastes. Furthermore, it is now known that the distribution of the taste buds themselves on the tongue is not uniform.

There are several factors that can influence the perception of taste. For example, you may have noticed that foods taste differently when you have a bad cold because your sense of smell is diminished. Temperature also plays a role; the perception of sweetness and bitterness are somewhat higher at elevated temperatures. Texture is important; whether a food is crunchy, creamy, chewy, etc. sways our perception of its taste. Appearance, environment, and even expectations can also shape our perceptions of taste.

pageData.subTitle: Smell
pageData.text: Unlike the basic taste sensations (of which there are only five have been identified) there are numerous smell responses, stimulated by many types of chemicals. This results in a large number and variety of odors. The organ of smell, the <button class='glossary-text'>olfactory epithelium</button>, is in the upper portion of each nasal cavity (Figure 2). This region contains olfactory receptor cells with tiny, hairlike cilia that are bathed in a layer of mucus. Gaseous odor molecules called <button class='glossary-text'>odorants</button> dissolve in this mucus layer and bind to receptor proteins in the membranes of the <button class='glossary-text'>sensory receptor</button> cells. There are thought to be hundreds of different types of odorant receptor proteins in the membranes of the olfactory receptor cells, enabling us to register the presence of many different odorant molecules. Axons from the receptor cells carry impulses through tiny perforations in the ethmoid bone of the skull (which lies between the nasal cavity from the brain) to the <button class='glossary-text'>olfactory bulb</button>, which lies under the frontal lobe of the brain.

In time, sensitivity to continuous odors may diminish or even become nonexistent, while the response to other odors is unimpaired. This phenomenon, known as “<button class='glossary-text'>olfactory fatigue,</button>” exemplifies <button class='glossary-text'>sensory adaptation</button>, a protective mechanism that keeps the nervous system from being so overwhelmed by ongoing sensory stimuli that it cannot register new stimuli.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram of the olfactory epithelium and olfactory bulb

pageData.question: Henry and his roommate live with Henry’s pet dog. Henry returns home from a two-week vacation to an unpleasant dog odor as his roommate forgot to bathe the dog. But Henry admits that after only a couple hours he no longer notices the smell. Which of the following best explains such a sensory adaptation?

options.text: This adaptation prevents old smells from overwhelming new smells.
This adaptation increases sensitivity in the other senses.
This adaptation protects the body from inhaled harmful gases.
This adaptation changes the perception of unpleasant smells to pleasant ones.
This adaptation resets the nervous system by blocking receptor proteins.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Olfactory fatigue is a temporary, naturally occurring phenomenon in your body that allows you to be more aware of new smells. It is informally known as “nose blindness”.

pageData.subTitle: Vision
pageData.text: The human eye is the sensory organ of the visual system and provides the ability to detect light and generate detailed visual images. The eye converts light waves to nerve impulses and transmits them to the brain where they are interpreted and converted into images. The eye (Figure 3) consists of two systems that are directly related to its visual function: the <button class='glossary-text'>refractive system</button> (the lens, <button class='glossary-text'>iris</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>cornea</button>) and the <button class='glossary-text'>photoreceptive system</button> (the retina). The refractive system focuses light onto a small region of the retina so that an inverted (upside down and backwards) image is formed. The retina contains two basic types of specialized, light-detecting <button class='glossary-text'>sensory receptor</button> cells known as <button class='glossary-text'>photoreceptors</button>.

Light enters the eyeball through the tough but transparent cornea (Figure 3). The amount of light that passes to the retina is regulated by the muscular iris, which can contract and relax in response to light, thereby adjusting the diameter of the opening in its center, the . In bright light, the diameter of the pupils will be small in order to protect the sensitive photoreceptors of the retina. In dim conditions, the diameter of the pupils will become larger to admit more light.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Diagram of the human eye showing the major structures and muscle attachments

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Pupil</button> diameter is an example of a <button class='glossary-text'>reflex</button>—an action that occurs automatically and involuntarily in response to a stimulus. Pupillary reflexes are observed under different lighting conditions. Changes in pupil size are brought about by shining a light directly onto one of a subject’s pupils; this is known as the <button class='glossary-text'>direct pupillary light reflex</button>. Shining a light on one pupil but not the other is a test of the <button class='glossary-text'>consensual pupillary light reflex</button>. This reflex will normally bring about constriction of the pupils of both eyes. The signal traveling from the illuminated eye via one <button class='glossary-text'>optic nerve</button> is relayed through a brain center with outputs to the motor nerves controlling the pupils of both eyes. Medical professionals commonly perform such tests during neurological exams to determine if the optic nerve and the cranial nerve that innervates the <button class='glossary-text'>iris</button> are functioning properly.

Light passes through the pupil to the lens (). In order for the eye to focus on near and far objects, the lens must change shape and project a clear, inverted image with the proper (the distance between the center of the lens and its focal point) through the thick, gelatinous onto the retina. When focusing on a near object, the muscular that holds the lens in place contracts, and the lens becomes rounder and thicker. When focusing on a distant object, the ciliary muscle relaxes, and the lens flattens. The combination of reflex actions by which the lens changes shape to keep the focal length constant is called . The closest point at which an eye can focus is termed the , or the minimum focal point, of vision. This can be measured by focusing on a sharply defined point and bringing it closer to the eye until it appears blurred or doubled. The distance from the eye to the object when blurring or doubling occurs is the near point.

The of the eye enables us to perceive detail. The amount of detail the eye can distinguish is known as . Normal visual acuity is called . For a person with (nearsightedness), the is too close. In other words, myopia causes distant objects to be out of focus because the image is projected in front of the retina. Myopia occurs if the eyeball is too deep or if the lens has too great a curvature. A person with (farsightedness) has a near point that is too far. Hyperopia makes it difficult to focus on nearby objects because the image strikes the retina before it is properly focused. Hyperopia occurs if the eyeball is not deep enough or if the lens does not have enough curvature.

The <button class='glossary-text'>Snellen eye examination chart</button> uses lines of progressively smaller letters to measure how well the subject’s eyes distinguish details at a distance of 20 ft compared to the average human. Visual acuity measurements are stated as a series of two numbers. The first number is the distance from the subject to the chart in feet. The second number is the distance in feet that a normal eye can see as clearly as the subject can at that distance. For example, normal human vision is 20/20. A score of 20/100 means that the test subject can see at a distance of 20 ft what a typical human eye can see from 100 ft away. On the other hand, a score of 20/15 means that the subject can see from 20 ft away what a typical observer must move 5 ft closer to see equally well.

<button class='glossary-text'>Astigmatism</button> is a condition in which the <button class='glossary-text'>cornea</button> or the lens is irregularly-shaped (Figure 4). This asymmetry causes incoming light rays to refract and converge improperly. Therefore, the light rays do not focus at a specific point on the retina. This results in blurred or distorted images. Many people possess some degree of astigmatism whether they realize it or not. The test for astigmatism uses a picture that resembles a spoked wheel made up of identical lines. A person with astigmatism will perceive thick, dark lines in certain areas when the chart is viewed from a distance because the cornea and/or the lens is not able to focus incoming light to a single point.

The <button class='glossary-text'>photoreceptors</button> of the retina are called <button class='glossary-text'>rods</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>cones</button> because of their distinctive shapes. Rods function in dim light and enable us to perceive shades of gray, such as what you see when your eyes adjust to darkness. There are about 120 million rods in each eye. Cones function in bright light and enable us to perceive sharp, colorful images. Human eyes contain about 6 million cones, which are greatly outnumbered by the rods except where they are concentrated in a small depression near the center of the retina called the <button class='glossary-text'>fovea centralis</button> (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button>). The fovea is surrounded by a larger, yellow-pigmented structure called the <button class='glossary-text'>macula lutea</button>, which absorbs UV light, thus protecting the cones.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagrams of the eye for emmetropia, myopia, hyperopia, and astigmatism

pageData.text: There are three different types of <button class='glossary-text'>cones</button>—red, green, and blue—and each type is sensitive to a different range of wavelengths of light. Different types of cones function together to enable responses to colors other than red, green, and blue. For instance, in order for the eye to register yellow light, red cones and green cones must work together. The <button class='glossary-text'>rods</button> and cones contact other nerve cells in the retina, which contain fibers that converge in a small area at the rear of the eyeball near the <button class='glossary-text'>fovea centralis</button> called the <button class='glossary-text'>optic disc</button> (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button>). This convergence of nerve fibers gives rise to the <button class='glossary-text'>optic nerve</button>, which leads to the brain. The brain processes and interprets signals relayed from the retina via the optic nerve.

Due to the peculiar arrangement of cells in the retina, there are no <button class='glossary-text'>photoreceptors</button> in the optic disc. Thus, an image that is projected onto the optic disc cannot be seen. It is for this reason that the optic disc is also known as the <button class='glossary-text'>blind spot</button>. We are usually unaware of the blind spot because of the overlap in visual stimuli received by both of the eyes together. Humans have <button class='glossary-text'>binocular vision</button>, meaning that our forward-facing eyes have overlapping <button class='glossary-text'>visual fields</button>. A visual field is an area that is visible to one eye, and each of our two eyes has its own visual field. We are usually unaware of the blind spot because the visual fields of the eyes overlap, and the brain tends to “fill in” these areas even if there is no overlap. The brain also corrects for the fact that the image projected onto the retina by the <button class='glossary-text'>refractive system</button> is inverted. The brain does this so that we perceive our surroundings in the correct orientation.

pageData.subTitle: Hearing
pageData.text: The human ear (Figure 5) is divided into three regions: the <button class='glossary-text'>external, middle, and inner ear</button>. The external ear consists of the outer flap that you see, known as the <button class='glossary-text'>pinna</button> (or auricle), which gathers incoming sound waves and funnels them through the <button class='glossary-text'>auditory canal</button> to the <button class='glossary-text'>tympanic membrane</button> (eardrum), which vibrates at the same frequency as the sound waves that contact it. Beyond the tympanic membrane lies the middle ear, an air-filled cavity in the temporal bone of the skull. The middle ear contains a chain of three tiny bones called the <button class='glossary-text'>auditory ossicles</button>: the malleus (hammer), the incus (anvil), and the stapes (stirrup). The end of the malleus is embedded in the tympanic membrane, and the stapes is attached to another membrane, the <button class='glossary-text'>oval window</button>, at the entrance to the inner ear. (In Figure 5, the oval window is covered by the flat base of the stapes.) The auditory ossicles transmit sound vibrations from the tympanic membrane to the sound-sensitive portion of the inner ear. Like the middle ear, the inner ear is situated within the temporal bone. The part of the inner ear concerned with the auditory system is a coiled, bony structure resembling a snail’s shell, known as the <button class='glossary-text'>cochlea</button>.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram showing the major structures of the outer, middle, and inner portions of the human ear

pageData.text: A closer look at the internal structure of the <button class='glossary-text'>cochlea</button> (Figure 6) reveals that it is partitioned into three chambers by two membranes. The <button class='glossary-text'>scala vestibuli</button>, which is filled with a fluid called <button class='glossary-text'>perilymph</button>, is separated from the <button class='glossary-text'>scala media</button> (cochlear duct) by the vestibular membrane. The cochlear duct is filled with a fluid called <button class='glossary-text'>endolymph</button> and is separated from the perilymphfilled <button class='glossary-text'>scala tympani</button> by the <button class='glossary-text'>basilar membrane</button>, upon which rests the <button class='glossary-text'>organ of Corti</button> (spiral organ). Because the scala media is separated from the adjacent scala vestibuli and scala tympani by membranes, it is sometimes called the <button class='glossary-text'>membranous labyrinth</button>.

Vibrations of the stapes at the <button class='glossary-text'>oval window</button> travel through the perilymph of the scala vestibuli. The vibrations pass to the basilar membrane. Since both the perilymph and endolymph are relatively incompressible fluids, excess pressure is released at the <button class='glossary-text'>round window</button> (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 5</button>) of the scala tympani, just below the oval window.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Diagram of the inner structure of the cochlea and the organ of Corti

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>organ of Corti</button> contains the motion-sensitive <button class='glossary-text'>sensory receptor</button> cells for hearing, called <button class='glossary-text'>hair cells</button>, which are sandwiched between the <button class='glossary-text'>basilar membrane</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>tectorial membrane</button> (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 6</button>). Vibrations of the basilar membrane cause numerous projections from the free surfaces of the hair cells, called <button class='glossary-text'>stereocilia</button> (which are actually specialized microvilli) to bend against the tectorial membrane. The bending of the stereocilia elicits nerve impulses which travel through the <button class='glossary-text'>cochlear ganglion</button> (spiral ganglion), and then via the cochlear nerve toward the brain. We detect volume because the louder the sound stimulus becomes, the higher the rate of nerve impulse traffic to the brain. We detect pitch because different parts of the basilar membrane resonate best at different frequencies of sound waves, which, in turn, stimulate different groups of hair cells.

pageData.question: What is another name for the eardrum?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The tympanic membrane vibrates at the same frequency as the sound waves entering the ear. This vibration is reminiscent of the way the taut skin on a drum vibrates when hit by a drumstick.

pageData.question: Which part of the inner ear is a coiled, bony structure resembling a snail’s shell?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The part of the inner ear concerned with the auditory system is a coiled, bony structure resembling a snail’s shell, known as the cochlea.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The human ear is divided into three regions: the external, middle, and inner ear. The external ear consists of the outer pinna which gathers incoming sound waves and funnels them through the auditory canal to the eardrum, which vibrates at the same frequency as the sound waves that contact it. The eardrum separates the outer ear from the middle ear; it also transmits vibrations to the cochlea of the inner ear via bones in the middle ear.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The human ear is divided into three regions: the external, middle, and inner ear. The external ear consists of the outer pinna which gathers incoming sound waves and funnels them through the auditory canal to the eardrum, which vibrates at the same frequency as the sound waves that contact it. The eardrum separates the outer ear from the middle ear; it also transmits vibrations to the cochlea of the inner ear via bones in the middle ear.

img.alt: Figure 5: Diagram showing the major structures of the outer, middle, and inner portions of the human ear

pageData.text: Because the <button class='glossary-text'>cochlea</button> is embedded in a bony cavity, vibrations transmitted through the entire skull can set the cochlear fluids in motion and elicit a sensation of sound. Therefore, a tuning fork placed against any portion of the skull can be heard even when both ears are securely plugged. This phenomenon is called <button class='glossary-text'>bone conduction</button> and will be tested in this investigation. Interestingly, the skull conducts low frequencies better than high frequencies. For this reason, you perceive your own voice to be lower in pitch than others do. It also explains why your voice sounds quite different to you when it is recorded and played back. Bone conduction bypasses some of the hearing mechanism. Therefore, headphones and other devices that utilize bone conduction can be used by people with certain types of hearing impairment.

The <button class='glossary-text'>Rinne test</button> compares the perception of sounds transmitted through air to sounds conducted through bone. It can indicate whether a person suffers from <button class='glossary-text'>conductive hearing loss</button>. Conductive hearing loss is the result of improper transmission of sound from the <button class='glossary-text'>tympanic membrane</button> to the ossicles, and typically involves a loss of the ability to hear faint sounds. Conductive hearing loss can result from accumulated fluid in the <button class='glossary-text'>middle ear</button> due to a cold, an ear infection, or improper drainage of the <button class='glossary-text'>Eustachian tube</button> (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 5</button>). Other causes of conductive hearing loss include perforation of the tympanic membrane, tumors, and the presence of foreign bodies or impacted ear wax. Normally, air conduction is greater than bone conduction. In the Rinne test, a low-frequency tuning fork is placed against the mastoid process (the bony bulge just behind the ear) until the subject can no longer hear the sound. Then, the vibrating tuning fork is moved in front of the ear. If the sound is not heard when the fork is moved in front of the ear, bone conduction is greater than air conduction, and something is preventing the transmission of sound to the cochlea.

pageData.subTitle: Equilibrium
pageData.text: The contains not only the , but also the , which contributes to our sense of equilibrium (balance) and is so named because it involves structures of the vestibule and semicircular canals (Figure 7). There are two main components of equilibrium.

<button class='glossary-text'>Static equilibrium</button> is the sense of how the body is positioned relative to gravity (up vs. down), and involves a type of receptor organ located in the vestibule, called a <button class='glossary-text'>macula</button> (Figure 7), of which there are two in each ear. One macula is horizontal, and the other is vertical. The maculae are responsive to changes in the angle of the head, as when the head is tilted forward or backward. The macula are also excited by linear acceleration or deceleration (speeding up or slowing down while moving straight ahead), as when moving forward or coming to a stop at a traffic light. A macula is a flat epithelium with <button class='glossary-text'>stereocilia</button>-bearing <button class='glossary-text'>hair cells</button> like those found in the cochlea. The stereocilia are embedded in a gelatinous <button class='glossary-text'>otolithic membrane</button>, which bears tiny calcium carbonate crystals called <button class='glossary-text'>otoliths</button>.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Diagram of the vestibular system, showing the parts of a macula and a crista ampullaris

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>otoliths</button> add mass to the membrane. When gravity pulls the otoliths and the membrane downward, the <button class='glossary-text'>hair cells</button> are stimulated to send signals to the brain along the vestibular nerve. Likewise, the inertia of the otolith-studded membrane drags on the <button class='glossary-text'>stereocilia</button> of the hair cells with changes in linear velocity.

<button class='glossary-text'>Dynamic equilibrium</button> is the sense of whether the head is in rotational motion, and in what direction said motion is occurring. It involves a type of sensory structure at the base of each semicircular canal called a <button class='glossary-text'>crista ampullaris</button> (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 7</button>) which is excited by changes in rotational velocity. The three semicircular canals are each oriented in a different plane and filled with <button class='glossary-text'>endolymph</button> like that of the cochlear duct. A crista is located in a small chamber at an end of each canal. Each crista has hair cells with stereocilia, much like those of a <button class='glossary-text'>macula</button>. However, in a crista, the stereocilia are embedded in a jellylike mass called a <button class='glossary-text'>cupula</button>. The ducts within the semicircular canals contain endolymph, and when the head rotates, this causes the endolymph to temporarily move in the opposite direction from the rotation. The shift in the flow of endolymph pulls on the cupula, bending the stereocilia of the hair cells, and a signal is sent along fibers of the vestibular nerve toward the brain. If the rotation continues, then the endolymph settles, and the hair cells are not stimulated until the rotation stops.

options.text: The sense of how the body is positioned relative to gravity.
The sense of whether the head is in rotational motion.
The arrangement of the three semicircular canals in the ear.
The sense of how fast the body is moving.
The body’s ability to stand still despite the rotation of the earth.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Special Senses investigation can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company, item 580528. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) described in the Safety and Procedure sections.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Other than Activity 2, in which your test subject will chew certain foods, neither you nor your partner should eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Wear PPE (goggles, gloves, and lab apron) for the smell and taste activities.
Clove and peppermint oils are eye, skin, and potentially respiratory irritants. Do not allow the test subject’s eyes or skin come into contact with these oils.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Wear a fresh pair of gloves to prepare each food sample (apple, onion, potato chunks, and carrot) for the taste and smell activity, and make sure your subject is not allergic to any of these foods.

For certain visual activities, a clear and unobstructed path is required. No foreign objects should touch the subject’s eyes. If anything does get into a subject’s eye, remove any material in the eye, if applicable, (using a sink sprayer or shower as an eyewash station), and clean and treat the eye. Seek medical attention as needed.

Do not conduct the light pupillary <button class='glossary-text'>reflex</button> tests on an individual with known light sensitivity of the eyes. If the subject experiences pain or discomfort, stop immediately. Seek medical attention if needed.

Please be aware that self-administered vision tests, including the eye chart tests, should never be used for diagnosis of visual conditions. Regular eye examinations by trained professionals are essential for diagnosing and treating diseases that can affect your vision.

The Rinne hearing test (Activity 9) is only one of a number of different hearing tests. In a clinical setting, the <button class='glossary-text'>Rinne test</button> is always done by medical professionals in conjunction with other tests. For this reason, you should not attempt to diagnose hearing impairments using the Rinne test described in this investigation. Be careful when tapping the tuning fork for the Rinne test. Do not strike your hand hard enough to cause injury.

For the equilibrium activity (Activity 10), a clear and unobstructed level space is required. The test subject should be barefoot or wearing shoes with a very low heel. Let the subject stand near a wall or chair to steady themselves if needed. Stand nearby and be prepared to catch the subject if they start to fall. If the subject experiences pain or discomfort, stop immedi-ately. Seek medical attention if needed.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Emily works in a professional kitchen as a dishwasher. She enjoys the smell of hot food cooking at the start of each shift; however, she realizes that it is not long before she no longer notices the food smells. Which of the following best describes the phenomenon Emily is experiencing at work?
The human tongue is much more sensitive to bitter tastes than sweet tastes. Which of the following best explains this lack of uniformity in our sense of taste?

options.text: Most poisons are bitter alkaloids, so bitterness may trigger vomiting.
There are twice as many receptors for bitter as for sweet on each taste bud.
The appearance of food can shape our perceptions of taste.
Sweet foods are not as calorically advantageous to humans as bitter foods.
The bitter-tasting region of the tongue is larger than the sweet-tasting region.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the consensual pupillary light reflex?

options.text: The pupils of both eyes will constrict.
The pupil into which the light is shining will constrict; the other pupil is static.
The pupil into which the light is shining will dilate; the other pupil constricts.
The pupils of both eyes will dilate.
The pupil into which the light is shining is static; the other pupil dilates.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following terms describes the closest point at which an eye can focus on an object?
The middle ear consists of which of the following structures?

When wearing hearing protection, such as ear plugs, you can still make out the sound of your own voice quite well even though the voice of another sounds faint. Which of the following best explains this phenomenon?

options.text: Skull bones can conduct voice vibrations to the cochlea.
The ears perceive low frequencies better than high frequencies.
Blocking the auditory canal enhances the sensitivity of the tympanic membrane.
Ear plugs prevent the release of excess pressure at the round window of the ear.
The vocal cords are directly connected to the ears by the eustachian tubes.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
Read the instructions carefully.
Obtain all necessary materials. Print out the Blind Spot Diagram.
In Activity 1, you will observe the phenomenon of <button class='glossary-text'>olfactory fatigue</button> in the test subject using clove and peppermint oils.

typeBefore.text: Caution: Pure peppermint and clove oils are eye and skin irritants, so be sure to wear your PPE—goggles, gloves, and lab apron—for this activity. Do not allow the test subject to contact the oils or materials that have had contact with the oils.

pageData.text: Place the plastic test tube in the cardboard test tube rack.
Place a cotton swab in the test tube vertically so that the head of the swab is above the top of the tube.
Place the rack and swab on a level surface approximately 30 cm (1 ft) away from, and just below, the nose of the test subject.
Have the test subject close the left nostril by pressing on it with the left index finger.
Place two drops of clove oil on the head of the cotton swab.

Start the timer. At the same time, have the subject gently waft the odor toward the nose, gently fanning with the right hand and inhaling through the right nostril, and then exhaling through the mouth.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Have the subject continue to sniff the odor and exhale through the mouth at a normal rate until the smell is no longer detectable or has greatly diminished. At this point, stop the timer and mark the elapsed time in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Have the subject release the left nostril, close the right nostril with the right index finger, and waft the odor of the clove oil toward the nose with the left hand. Start the timer.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Have the subject continue to sniff the odor and exhale through the mouth at a normal rate until the smell is no longer detectable or has greatly diminished. At this point, stop the timer and mark the elapsed time for the left nostril in Data Table 1.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Place the used swab in a resealable plastic bag, and seal the bag completely.
Repeat the procedure using the peppermint oil, and record the results in Data Table 1.
Put the remaining swab in the resealable bag, and close the bag.

In Activity 2, you will examine the relationship between taste and smell by asking the test subject to identify raw food samples in two blind taste tests, one with the nostrils closed and one with the nostrils open.

typeBefore.text: Caution: Check before you begin this activity to ensure that your subject is not allergic to any of the foods that will be used. If the subject is allergic, and a non-allergic subject is not available, skip this activity. Wear gloves while preparing the food and feeding it to the test subject. Have paper towels, tissues, or a trash can nearby so the subject can spit out the food if they do not wish to eat it.

pageData.text: Have the subject sit with eyes closed, mouth open, and nostrils pinched shut.

Using a toothpick or a fork, pick up one piece of the multiple food pieces (a small, bite-sized piece of either a peeled apple, sweet onion, raw potato, or a carrot) in random order, from a plate and place it in the subject’s mouth.
Have the subject slowly chew the food and try to identify it. Record the results in Data Table 2.
Repeat steps 1–3 with another piece of the same food, allowing the subject to keep the nostrils open. Record the results.
Have the subject rinse the mouth with water.
Repeat steps 1–5 with the remaining pieces of food.

In Activity 3, you will use the pen light to observe the <button class='glossary-text'>direct pupillary light reflex</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>consensual pupillary light reflex</button> in the test subject.

typeBefore.text: Caution: Do not conduct these tests on an individual with known light sensitivity of the eyes. If the subject experiences pain or discomfort, stop immediately. Seek medical attention if needed.

pageData.text: Have your subject sit comfortably. First, observe your subject’s eyes in bright light. The pupils of both eyes should be constricted.

Dim the lights in the room where you are conducting this activity. Have the subject sit with eyes closed for 2 minutes. Have the subject open the eyes, and then examine the subject’s eyes. Both pupils should be dilated.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Now that you have observed your subject’s pupils in both constricted and dilated conditions, you will test the . Shine the penlight at the subject’s left eye, and observe the change in size in the left eye. Note the results in Data Table 3 under Direct Pupillary Light Reflex. Repeat with the right eye.

Have the subject sit with eyes closed for 2 minutes. Then have the subject open the eyes, and shine the light in the left eye while the subject holds a hand over the right eye. After a few seconds, have the subject uncover the right eye, and observe the pupil size. Note the results in Data Table 3 under the section. Repeat, reversing the eyes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: In Activity 4, you will use the blind spot diagram to observe the blind spot phenomenon in the test subject.

Have the subject sit comfortably. Have the subject close the left eye and hold the Blind Spot Diagram (which should be printed and cut out) at arm’s length so that the plus sign is directly in front of the right eye and the dot is oriented to the outside of the face (toward the right ear).
Direct the subject to stare directly at the plus sign. Without changing focus, have the subject slowly move the diagram closer until the dot disappears.
Measure the distance (in cm) from the subject’s face to the diagram at the point where the dot disappears.
Write this distance in Data Table 4.

Repeat the test with the subject’s right eye closed to find the <button class='glossary-text'>blind spot</button> on the left eye. This time, hold the diagram such that the dot points outside to the left ear and the plus sign is directly in front of the left eye.
In Activity 5, you will determine the <button class='glossary-text'>near point</button> for each of the test subject’s eyes.
Obtain a straight pin from the materials kit.
Have the test subject place the “0” end of a metric ruler on the cheek near the outer edge of the left eye.
Hold an index card over the subject’s right eye; if an index card is not available, hold a hand over the right eye.
Have the subject hold the pin, point upward, and slowly move it along the outer edge of the ruler toward the left eye.
When the subject can no longer focus on the pin, note the distance from the pin to the cheek using the ruler. This is the <button class='glossary-text'>near point</button> for the subject’s left eye.
Record the value in Data Table 5.

Repeat this process using the subject’s right eye and cheek to determine the near point of the right eye. This time, place the ruler on the right cheek, and cover the left eye with the index card or the subject’s hand.
Record the right eye value in Data Table 5.

In Activity 6, you will use the <button class='glossary-text'>Snellen eye examination chart</button> to determine the <button class='glossary-text'>visual acuity</button> value of each of the test subject’s eyes. These tests should be conducted without any corrective lenses, although these can be replaced if the subject is unable to read any of the lines on the eye chart.

Hang the <button class='glossary-text'>Snellen eye examination chart</button> on a wall. Measure 20 ft from the chart and mark the location on the floor with a piece of tape, sticky note, or other small object.
If corrective lenses are usually worn, have the subject remove them for this test.
Have the subject stand 20 ft from the Snellen eye examination chart while you stand at the chart.
Have the test subject cover the left eye with an index card (or a hand if a card is not available).
Point to each line of the chart, and wait for the subject to call out the printed letters.

Continue until the subject can no longer read the letters correctly or until all the lines are read. (If most of the text cannot be read, have the subject replace the corrective lenses and repeat the test. Please note in the data table that corrective lenses were used.)
In Data Table 6, write down the value that appears to the left of the last line that was read correctly.
Have the subject move the index card (or hand) to cover the right eye, and repeat the test.
If desired, you may switch roles with the subject and repeat this activity.

In Activity 7, you will use the <button class='glossary-text'>astigmatism</button> test chart to determine whether astigmatism is present in each of the test subject’s eyes. These tests should be conducted without any corrective lenses, although contact lenses can be left in if they do not correct for astigmatism.

Hang the <button class='glossary-text'>astigmatism</button> test chart on the wall. Measure a distance of 8–10 ft, and mark this spot on the floor with a piece of masking tape, sticky note, or other small object.
If glasses are usually worn, have the subject remove them for this test. (Contact lenses that do not correct for astigmatism do not have to be removed.)
Have the subject stand 8–10 ft from the astigmatism test chart at the location marked on the floor.
Direct the subject to cover one eye with an index card or hand. Then, have the subject view the astigmatism test chart and state whether any thick, dark lines are observed on the chart.
Note the result in Data Table 7.
Then, have the subject move the index card or hand to cover the right eye, and repeat the test.
If desired, you may switch roles with the subject and repeat this activity.
In Activity 8, you will use the tuning fork to observe how skull bones conduct sound.

typeBefore.text: Caution: Neither of the hearing tests in this investigation should be used for the diagnosis of hearing impairments outside of a clinical setting, where additional tests would be conducted by medical professionals. Be careful when tapping the tuning fork; do not to use excessive force, which could injure your hand.

Note: In this activity, you should move the tuning fork in a series of smooth movements onto, away from, and back onto the skull of the test subject. The fork should vibrate the entire time, and the subject should keep his or her ears plugged for the duration of the test.

pageData.text: Instruct the subject to plug both ears with their fingers.

Hold the tuning fork on its side, and tap just one of the prongs briskly against the heel of your hand, about 1 /3 of the way down from the top of the prong. This should cause the tuning fork to resonate. Then, place the end of the handle against the top of the subject’s head.
Move the tuning fork about 1 ft away from the subject’s head.
Return the tuning fork to rest again on the subject’s skull.
Have the subject state whether they could hear the tuning fork on the top of the head, when it was moved away, and when it was returned.
Record the subject’s answers in Data Table 8.
Make sure the subject’s ears are still plugged. Strike the tuning fork a second time, and place the base of the fork against one of the subject’s temples (either side is acceptable).
Have the subject state whether they could hear the tuning fork at the temple and, if so, whether the sound was the same intensity in both ears.
Record the answers in Data Table 8.
In Activity 9, you will use the tuning fork to conduct a <button class='glossary-text'>Rinne test</button> for each of the test subject’s ears.

Strike the tuning fork firmly on the palm of your hand, and then hold the base of the fork against the mastoid process, the bony bump behind the lobe of the ear to be tested. When the subject no longer hears the sound produced by the tuning fork, hold the vibrating prongs in front of the ear being tested. Do not re-strike the tuning fork.

Ask the subject if he or she can now hear the tuning fork. If the subject can hear the tuning fork in front of the ear after sound conduction via the mastoid process has stopped, transmission deafness is not present, and hearing is considered unimpaired. Record the results in Data Table 9.
Repeat the test for the subject’s other ear, and record these results as well.

In Activity 10, you will conduct a series of standing equilibrium tests in which you will ask the test subject to stand with their feet in various configurations with and without their eyes closed. You will record the time at which they lose their balance, or a maximum time of 30 seconds.

typeBefore.text: Caution: Make sure the test subject is standing on a level surface and either barefoot or wearing shoes with a very low heel. Have the subject stand near a wall or a chair for support if necessary. Stand nearby, and be prepared to catch the subject if they start to fall. If the subject performing this activity experiences pain or discomfort, stop immediately. Seek medical attention if needed.
Note: For this activity, stop the timer if the test subject cannot maintain the test position, and record the time elapsed in Data Table 10.

pageData.text: Have the subject stand still with feet together, arms crossed over the chest, and eyes open for up to 30 seconds. Record all results in Data Table 10.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Have the subject stand still with feet together, arms crossed over the chest, and eyes closed for up to 30 seconds. Record the results.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Have the subject stand still with both feet flat on the floor, and the heel of one foot directly in front of the toes of the other foot (the subject chooses the foot arrangement), arms crossed over the chest, and eyes open for up to 30 seconds. Record the results.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 1 through 3 in this investigation. Before starting any activities, print the blind spot diagram, peel and cut samples of raw apple, carrot, onion, and potato, and locate a test subject. In Activity 1, you will conduct an olfactory fatigue test on each nostril using clove oil. Then, you will conduct the same test using peppermint oil. In Activity 2, you will conduct a blind taste test for four different raw food samples with the nostrils closed. Then, conduct the blind taste test again with the nostrils open.  If so, go forward if not go back conduct a direct pupillary light reflex test for each eye Then, conduct a consensual pupillary light reflex test for each eye.left and right eyes evaluated? If so, go forward if not go back.

This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 4 through 7 in this investigation. In Activity 4, you will conduct a blind spot test for each eye.  If so, go forward if not go back.In activity 5, you will conduct a near point test for each eye.  you will examine each eye using a Snellen eye chart. You will determine the visual acuity value.  go forward if not go back to the first step in activity 6.In activity 7, you will examine each eye using an astigmatism test chart.

This map describes the procedural workflow for Activities 8 through 10 in this investigation. In activity 8, you will conduct a bone conduction test on the top of the head and on the temple. In activity 9, you will conduct a Rinne test for each ear. In activity 10, you will conduct three different types of standing equilibrium tests with the eyes open and closed: with feet together, feet heel to toe, and on one leg only.

data.title: Accommodation
data.content: Reflex actions by which the lens changes shape to focus on a distant object

data.title: Astigmatism
data.content: A condition in which the cornea or lens is irregularly-shaped

data.title: Auditory canal
data.content: Part of the external ear that gathers incoming sound waves and funnels them through the auditory canal to the tympanic membrane

data.title: Auditory ossicles
data.content: The chain of three tiny bones in the middle ear: the malleus (hammer), the incus (anvil), and the stapes (stirrup)

data.title: Basilar membrane
data.content: A membrane extending from the bony shelf of the cochlea to the outer wall

data.title: Binocular vision
data.content: Vision generated by overlapping visual fields as a result of forward-facing eyes

data.title: Blind spot
data.content: The small portion of the back of the retina where there are no rods or cones and the optic nerve enters the eyeball

data.title: Bone conduction
data.content: The transmission of low-pitched sounds to the inner ear through vibrations of the skull

data.title: Ciliary body
data.content: Located immediately posterior to the iris, is a muscular structure that is attached to the lens

data.title: Cochlea
data.content: The part of the inner ear concerned with the auditory system; it is a coiled, bony structure resembling a snail’s shell

data.title: Cochlear ganglion
data.content: The cell bodies of the neurons that receive auditory information; also called spiral ganglion

data.title: Conductive hearing loss
data.content: A type of hearing loss featuring improper transmission of sound from the tympanic membrane to the ossicles; it typically involves the inability to hear faint sounds

data.title: Cone
data.content: A photoreceptor that function in bright light and facilitates the perception of color

data.title: Consensual pupillary light reflex
data.content: A change in pupil size brought about by shining a light onto a subject's other pupil

data.title: Cornea
data.content: The transparent part of the coat of the eyeball that covers the iris and pupil

data.title: Crista ampullaris
data.content: The sensory structure at the base of each semicircular canal

data.title: Cupula
data.content: A cluster of sensitive hairs embedded in a jellylike mound; plural, cupulae

data.title: Direct pupillary light reflex
data.content: A change in pupil size brought about by shining a light onto one of a subject’s pupils

data.title: Dynamic equilibrium
data.content: The sense of whether the head is in rotational motion and in what direction said motion is occurring

data.title: Emmetropia
data.content: The condition defined by the absence of refractive errors in the eye

data.title: Endolymph
data.content: The fluid that fills the scala media

data.title: Eustachian tube
data.content: The hollow structure that extends from the middle ear to the throat and allows for drainage; also called the pharyngotympanic tube or the auditory tube

data.title: External ear
data.content: The part of the ear that is visible

data.title: Focal length
data.content: The distance from the center of the lens to where the image is formed on the retina; focal length changes when the ciliary codies change the shape of the lens

data.title: Fovea centralis
data.content: A small depression near the center of the retina where rods are concentrated

data.title: General senses
data.content: The sensations of touch, pressure, pain, temperature, vibration, and proprioception

data.title: Hair cells
data.content: Motion-sensitive sensory receptor cells for hearing

data.title: Homeostasis
data.content: The self-regulating process by which biological systems maintain stability while adjusting to environmental changes

data.title: Hyperopia
data.content: The condition defined by a near point that is farther than normal, making it difficult to focus on nearby objects; also called farsightedness

data.title: Inner ear
data.content: The portion of the ear that contains the hearing and balance apparatus; also called the bony labyrinth

data.title: Iris
data.content: The colored part of the eye

data.title: Macula
data.content: Sensory cells in the inner ear

data.title: Macula lutea
data.content: Absorbs UV light and protects the cones

data.title: Membranous labyrinth
data.content: The membranes that separate the scala media from the adjacent scala vestibuli and scala tympani

data.title: Middle ear
data.content: An air-filled cavity in the temporal bone of the skull; it consists of three bones: the hammer (malleus), the anvil (incus) and the stirrup (stapes)

data.title: Myopia
data.content: The condition defined by a near point that is closer than normal, making it difficult to focus on distant objects; also called nearsightedness

data.title: Near point
data.content: The closest point at which an eye can focus; also called the minimum focal point

data.title: Odorant
data.content: Gaseous odor molecules

data.title: Olfactory bulb
data.content: A rounded mass of tissue that contains several types of nerve cells that are involved in the sense of smell; it lies under the frontal lobe of the brain

data.title: Olfactory epithelium
data.content: A specialized tissue inside the nasal cavity that is involved in smell

data.title: Olfactory fatigue
data.content: Diminished or nonexistant sensitivity to continuous odors while the response to other odors is unimpaired

data.title: Optic disc
data.content: A small area at the rear of the eyeball where rods and cones contact other nerve cells in the retina

data.title: Optic nerve
data.content: The convergence of nerve fibers in the optic disc; this nerve leads to the brain

data.title: Organ of Corti (spiral organ)
data.content: Structure within the cholea containing the tectorial membrane and hair cells which relays nerve impulses from the vibration of sound to the cochlear ganglion

data.title: Otolithic membrane
data.content: Gelatinous membrane in which the stereocillia of vestibular hair cells and otoliths are embedded

data.title: Otoliths
data.content: Small calcium carbonate crystals embedded in the otolithic membrane

data.title: Oval window
data.content: At the entrance to the inner ear

data.title: Papilla
data.content: A projection from the surface of the tongue; plural papillae

data.title: Perilymph
data.content: The fluid that fills the scala vestibuli

data.title: Photoreceptive system
data.content: The retina

data.title: Photoreceptors
data.content: Specialized light-detecting sensory receptor cells in the retina

data.title: Pinna
data.content: The outer flap of the ear; also called the auricle

data.title: Proprioception
data.content: The perception or awareness of the position and movement of the body; also called kinesthesia

data.title: Pupil
data.content: The round opening in the center of the iris

data.title: Reflex
data.content: An involuntary, practically instantaneous response to a stimulus

data.title: Refractive system
data.content: The lens, iris, and cornea, which together focus light onto a small region of the retina so that an inverted (upside down and backwards) image is formed

data.title: Rinne test
data.content: A test which compares the perception of sounds transmitted through air to sounds conducted through bone

data.title: Rod
data.content: A photoreceptor cell that functions in dim light

data.title: Round window
data.content: An ear structure that bulges in response to pressure created by perilymph and endolymph, which enables the auditory receptors to be activated

data.title: Scala media
data.content: The central duct of the cochlea in the inner ear containing the sensory cells and is filled with endolymph

data.title: Scala tympani
data.content: Located on the outside of the cochlear duct and is filled with perilymph fluid

data.title: Scala vestibuli
data.content: The superior-most duct of the cochlea duct and which is filled with perilymph fluid

data.title: Sensory adaptation
data.content: A protective mechanism that keeps the nervous system from being so overwhelmed by ongoing sensory stimuli that it cannot register new stimuli; also called olfactory fatigue

data.title: Sensory receptor
data.content: A type of specialized nerve cell located throughout the skin, muscles, and tendons; it detects the general senses

data.title: Snellen eye examination chart
data.content: An eye examination chart that uses lines of progressively smaller letters to measure how well the subject’s eyes distinguish details at a distance of 20 feet compared to the average human

data.title: Special senses
data.content: The sensations of taste (gustation), smell (olfaction), vision, hearing (audition), and equilibrium (balance); detected via sensory receptors associated with dedicated sensory organs

data.title: Static equilibrium
data.content: The sense of how the body is positioned relative to gravity (up vs. down), and involves a type of receptor organ located in the vestibule, called a macula

data.title: Stereocilia
data.content: Specialized microvilli

data.title: Tastant
data.content: A water-soluble chemical that produces a taste sensation

data.title: Taste bud
data.content: Nerve endings on the tongue and in the lining of the mouth

data.title: Tympanic membrane
data.content: The membrane that separates the outer ear from the middle ear, and which vibrates at the same frequency as the sound waves that contact it; also called the eardrum

data.title: Vestibular system
data.content: Contributes to a sense of equilibrium (balance) and is so named because it involves structures of the vestibule and semicircular canals

data.title: Visual acuity
data.content: The amount of detail the eye can distinguish

data.title: Visual field
data.content: The total area in which objects can be seen by an eye when it is fixed straight at a point

data.title: Vitreous body
data.content: Eye, the posterior with a gelatinous fluid, contribute to maintaining the spherical shape of the eye
